distribution.text: Copyright 2024 SUSE LLC. All rights reserved.

notes.text:
This update for dnsmasq fixes the following issues:

- Version update to 2.90:
- CVE-2023-50387: Fixed a Denial Of Service while trying to validate specially crafted DNSSEC responses. (bsc#1219823)
- CVE-2023-50868: Fixed a Denial Of Service while trying to validate specially crafted DNSSEC responses. (bsc#1219826)
- CVE-2023-28450: Default maximum EDNS.0 UDP packet size should be 1232. (bsc#1209358)
notes.title: Description of the patch

notes.text: CSAF 2.0 data is provided by SUSE under the Creative Commons License 4.0 with Attribution (CC-BY-4.0).
notes.title: Terms of use

notes.text: An issue was discovered in Dnsmasq before 2.90. The default maximum EDNS.0 UDP packet size was set to 4096 but should be 1232 because of DNS Flag Day 2020.
notes.title: CVE description

notes.text: Certain DNSSEC aspects of the DNS protocol (in RFC 4033, 4034, 4035, 6840, and related RFCs) allow remote attackers to cause a denial of service (CPU consumption) via one or more DNSSEC responses, aka the "KeyTrap" issue. One of the concerns is that, when there is a zone with many DNSKEY and RRSIG records, the protocol specification implies that an algorithm must evaluate all combinations of DNSKEY and RRSIG records.
notes.title: CVE description

recommended: SUSE Linux Enterprise High Performance Computing 15 SP4-ESPOS:dnsmasq-2.90-150400.16.3.1.aarch64
SUSE Linux Enterprise High Performance Computing 15 SP4-ESPOS:dnsmasq-2.90-150400.16.3.1.x86_64

notes.text: The Closest Encloser Proof aspect of the DNS protocol (in RFC 5155 when RFC 9276 guidance is skipped) allows remote attackers to cause a denial of service (CPU consumption for SHA-1 computations) via DNSSEC responses in a random subdomain attack, aka the "NSEC3" issue. The RFC 5155 specification implies that an algorithm must perform thousands of iterations of a hash function in certain situations.
notes.title: CVE description
